questions.question: What is the central philosophy of this course?
options: Traditional lecture-driven learning with isolated technical mastery
Studio-based software development experience building real software for a real client
Individual project work with no collaboration
Focus on theoretical concepts without practical application
questions.explanation: This course is designed as a studio-based software development experience where students work as a development team building real software for a real client, operating under real technical, organizational, and time constraints.

questions.question: What are the two main phases of the course?
options: Planning and Implementation
Design and Testing
Software Design Foundations (Weeks 1-8) and Building New Features (Weeks 9-15)
Individual Work and Team Work
questions.explanation: The course is organized into Phase 1: Software Design Foundations (Weeks 1-8) where teams work on similar features using a shared starter system, and Phase 2: Building New Features (Weeks 9-15) where teams work on distinct vertical feature slices in a shared codebase.

questions.question: What is the primary goal of Phase 1 (Software Design Foundations)?
options: To build as many features as possible
To focus on process, coordination, and reasoning rather than feature differentiation
To work independently without collaboration
To learn only backend development
questions.explanation: During Phase 1, all teams work on similar features and problems. This deliberate constraint allows students to focus on process, coordination, and reasoning, rather than feature differentiation.

questions.question: What is the client context for this course?
options: A social media platform
An e-commerce website
A cross-platform application supporting parents of young children with motor delays and clinicians
A gaming application
questions.explanation: Students will collaborate with a real-world client focused on supporting parents of young children with motor delays. The project involves building a cross-platform application (web and mobile) using PostgreSQL, FastAPI, React, and React Native.

questions.question: What is emphasized in Phase 2 (Building New Features)?
options: Working on similar features as other teams
Individual work without collaboration
Collaboration at scale, integration and coordination, managing tradeoffs
Avoiding client interaction
questions.explanation: Phase 2 emphasizes collaboration at scale, integration and coordination, managing tradeoffs between scope, quality, and time, and delivering a coherent product to a real stakeholder.

questions.question: Why is regular attendance essential in this course?
options: Because all lectures are recorded and attendance is optional
Because learning depends heavily on in-person participation, critique, and collaboration
Because there are no assignments outside of class
Because the final exam is worth 100% of the grade
questions.explanation: Because this is a studio course, learning depends heavily on in-person participation, critique, and collaboration. Many skills required to deliver value to a client can only be practiced in a shared, synchronous setting.

questions.question: What happens after three (3) unexcused absences?
options: The student is automatically withdrawn from the course
The student receives a formal warning that they are at risk of failing the course
No action is taken
The student's grade is automatically reduced by one letter
questions.explanation: After three (3) unexcused absences, the student will receive a formal warning that they are at risk of failing the course due to insufficient participation in required studio work.

questions.question: What happens after four (4) or more unexcused absences?
options: The student automatically passes the course
No action is taken
One or more actions may occur: reduction/cap on participation credit, removal from team-based work, or recommendation to withdraw
The student receives extra credit
questions.explanation: After four (4) or more unexcused absences, one or more of the following actions may occur: reduction or cap on participation credit, removal from team-based work and reassignment to an individual alternative, or recommendation to withdraw from the course.

questions.question: What is assessed in Code Reviews?
options: The correctness of every line of code
Substantive review comments that address behavior, design, testing, or tradeoffs
Only spelling and grammar
The number of comments made
questions.explanation: Code Reviews are assessed for substance and engagement (e.g., questions about behavior, design tradeoffs, or testing), not for 'correctness.'

questions.question: How are students evaluated in this course?
options: Solely based on team output
Solely based on individual work with no team collaboration
As individual contributors working within team-based projects
Based only on final exam performance
questions.explanation: Students are evaluated as individual contributors working within team-based projects. You will collaborate closely with others, but your grade is not determined solely by your team's output. Assessment is based on observable individual contributions made in a team context.

questions.question: Which of the following is assessed at the individual level?
options: Integrated system behavior
Sprint demos and milestones
Pull Requests (PRs) authored by you
Client-facing deliverables
questions.explanation: Pull Requests (PRs) are assessed at the individual level. Your authored PRs will be evaluated for clarity of intent, scope, correctness, use of tests, and adherence to project conventions.

questions.question: What is one of the learning objectives of this course?
options: To memorize all programming languages
To contribute effectively to an existing software system
To work only on new projects from scratch
To avoid using tests
questions.explanation: One learning objective is to contribute effectively to an existing software system, including understanding and working within established architectural patterns, and making scoped, testable changes using professional workflows.

questions.question: What is the relationship between strong team outcomes and individual grades?
options: Strong team outcomes automatically guarantee high individual grades
Strong individual effort overrides lack of participation in required studio work
Strong team outcomes do not automatically guarantee high individual grades, and strong individual effort does not override lack of participation
Individual grades are completely independent of team outcomes
questions.explanation: Strong team outcomes do not automatically guarantee high individual grades, and strong individual effort does not override a lack of participation in required studio work. Grades reflect how you contribute, not just what the team produces.
